METEROLOGICAL OFFICE, 
63, VICTORIA STREET, LONDON, S.W. 
7th April 1908. 
H.L.B.T. 
<u>Meteorology of the Antarctic<\u>. 
Dear Sir Archibald, 
I do not think I have done anything to convey the 
impression that Antarctic Meteorology ended with the volume 
now in the press. I have on various occasions discussed with 
you the procedure with regard to the rest of the material, 
which consists of about 1,000 double-folio sheets of observa-
tions and maps of circum-polar  observations, and the records 
of the autographic instruments at he winter quarters. 
With regard to the former, I have on various occasions 
suggested to you, and I understand you to concur in the sugges-
tion, that the maps should be reproduced on a very much reduced 
scale, at the rate of about 16 maps to the double page, showing 
the salient features for each day. 
The understanding was, that a sum should be assigned 
for the issue of these maps with a few pages of explanatory 
text, as a second volume of meteorological work. The sum 
mentioned was £250 to £300, but my grounds for mentioning these 
particular figures do not amount to more than guess work. 
The ground-work of each sheet, which would be printed 
in colour, would be the same for all; the line work, which 
would have to be on a separate stone, would of course, be 
different for each. 
Captain Hepworth has been preparing a draft, and his 
view is, that we cannot get more than 12 maps on an opening. 
The estimate required is therefore for 170 quarto pages of 
two-stone 
Sir Archibald Geikie, D.C.L., Sc.D., L.L.D., 
The Royal Society, 
Burlington House, W.
